Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[SAS Token] Create get only uri methods for files." (#8424) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: Added new methods to retrieve the file/package uri. This will help us support sas tokens that are not generated on methods that returns an uri with the sas token embeded.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Remove logic with ImagesRewritten & remove the feature flag" (#8425) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/8406#discussion_r568042833

Since we are tightening validation for images in markdown, we can remove the 'ImagesRewritten' functionality after the allow list is stabilized.  

remove the feature flag since it will become default behavior

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Implement dotnet nuget sign command" (#10581) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Copied from : https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10090#issuecomment-705086230

- [ ]  [15 hours] Add a new dotnet sign at src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.CommandLine.XPlat/Commands/Signing/SignCommand.cs.

Note that this new command should perform similar input validation as the existing NuGet.exe sign command at src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.CommandLine/Commands/SignCommand.cs. For example, some option combinations are invalid/required.
Because the <package-path> argument can expand to multiple packages, the new sign command must support multiple packages. (I think the spec has a typo in that the sign usage example should show <package-path>...* as the verify command does.) SignArgs.PackagePath should be deprecated in favor of a new IReadOnlyList<string> PackagePaths property.

- [ ]  [10 hours] Respect the --interactive option. Note that the option has flipped from NuGet.exe's -NonInteractive option.

See all comments in NuGet/NuGet.Client#3069.
Propagating the NonInteractive option from SignArgs in SignCommandRunner seems like the best option.
If the default behavior must change as a result of this work, please sync with Claire Novotny.
It may be worth adding a test for the non-interactive case. The test may actually be provided by a later task below.
 

- [ ] [5 hours] Add basic tests for dotnet sign that verify on all platforms:

Exit code, output, errors, etc. for argument validation failures.
With valid arguments the command creates a good, signed package.

- [ ]  [10 hours] Expand SignCommandRunner tests to verify different options on all platforms.

When the certificate is a file path.
When the certificate is in a certificate store.
When the certificate is password-protected.

- [ ]  [10 hours] Add to dotnet autocompletion for the sign command.

- [ ]  [5 hours] Add/update dotnet documentation for the sign command`

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "How are fallback paths populated into nuget.g.props for NuGetPackageFolders?  " (#10580) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
We have one user getting an unexpected Xamarian path added to the list of NuGetPackageFolders in his *.nuget.g.props files when running dotnet.exe restore (using version 5.0.102), for which we have not been able to track down the reason.  

Specifically our environment has a nuget.config that clears all earlier setting and only adds very specific enlistment known paths (globalPackagesFolder is set, while RepositoryPath is cleared).  We also sandbox environment variables that are allowed to pass through to the processes being run (so things like NUGET_PACKAGES are not set).  

Most folks just have globalPackagesFolder and a NuGetFallbackFolder under the sdk folder, though the user above has a third folder (before the sdk location) for C:\Microsoft\Xamarin\NuGet\ that we want to remove from that list.  We need to understand how that's getting added as a first step.  

This matters for our team as we use BuildXL to distribute our builds, and the extra path is being read by dotnet.exe causing mismatches to what is statically declared for our BuildXL graph.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "why restore folder has different structure between nuget global cache and nuget install" (#10560) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
When I used VS IDE install a nuget package and enter the global nuget cache, its structure is like `C:\Users\xxx\.nuget\packages\castle.core\4.4.0`.

However, when I used command line like  `nuget install castle.core -Version 4.4.0 -Source C:\LocalNuGetPackages -OutputDirectory C:\packages`.

The unpack structure is like `C:\packages\castle.core.4.4.0`.


`$(PackageId)\$(PackageVersion)\` and `$(PackageId).$(PackageVersion)\`.


Why the structure is different and can it be the same? The same structure could help us including anyone who faces the same situation in the future have a good user experience.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Missing format default on `nuget list source`" (#10457) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Similar to https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/9337, it seems issue reemerged recently.

## Details about Problem
When calling 
```
nuget sources list
```
error is thrown, instead of using detailed as default like it was in previous versions.
```
invalid value for --format: None. Allowed values: 'detailed' or 'short'
```

Product version: 
NuGet Version: 5.8.1 (installed by azdo nuget installer task) - throws 

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: 
NuGet Version: 5.7.0.6726 (commandline version) - works as expected

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "NuGet restore failing on .NET 5 for Debian-based OSes" (#49) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Hey Everyone,

Our preliminary investigation shows that .NET 5 restore is broken for Debian-based operating systems including Docker thus resulting in error messages like:

```
error NU3037: Package 'System.Memory 4.5.3' from source 'https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json': The author primary signature validity period has expired.
```

### [Debian Versions](https://www.debian.org/releases/)
- We're currently aware that Debian 10 ("buster") and earlier versions are affected. ‚ùå
- We do know that Debian testing ("bullseye") and later are not affected. ‚úî

This is because of an [issue reported](https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=962596) in the `ca-certificates` package in which the root CA being used are not trusted and must be installed manually due to [Symantec Issues](https://wiki.mozilla.org/CA:Symantec_Issues). Because this issue has been resolved recently in version 20210119 of this package, it is not available in a Debian version as provided in `dotnet-docker` for `buster-slim` today.

## Workarounds

- Manually update the [ca-certificates](https://packages.debian.org/bullseye/ca-certificates) package to version 20210119 including a `bullseye` or later version.
- Consider using a different Debian-based Docker image such as `alpine` or `focal`.
 
## Solution

We're currently working to update the `dotnet-docker`'s `buster-slim` image to update the `ca-certificates` package to 20210119 that resolves this issue. We are however currently verifying this is a viable solution with no large diffs between the `buster` and `bullseye` releases.

Additionally, the `ca-certificates` package is due to be installed in the Debian FTP archive which will promote this fix to the `buster` release in the next few days to which an updated `buster-slim` image will be prepared and released when available.

## Stay Updated

- We are continuing to investigate this issue and will let you know more as we find out.
- We'll continue to update the discussion at https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10491.
- We will also continue posting updates on https://status.nuget.org and on Twitter @NuGet.
